author: Frank McKee
summary: The author argues that the main obstacle to a better life for everyone is a set of outdated ideas that people hold. By proposing a new set of ideas, he suggests that society can overcome its current issues such as overproduction leading to starvation and inefficient use of resources.
text:
SAYS MEN MUST ADOPT A NEW SET OF IDEAS

Letters to the Editor To the Editor of The Press: The faculty which ideas seem to possess of materializing into concrete facts is one of the miracles of science. Widely held beliefs tend to come true even though they defy logic. If everyone believes that a bank is going to fall, the chances are that it will fall. Conversely, if everyone believes that the bank will pull through, the chances are that it will pull through. On the national scale, there are no physical obstacles to an abundant life for everyone. The obstacles are purely mental. Starving because of overproduction, or freezing on top of mountains of coal, going to jail without benefit of counsel, or dying without solace of medicine (while doctors and lawyers complain about overcrowded professions), life's supreme handicap is always in the realm of ideas. I can visualize nothing better in the direction of human affairs until a new set of ideas has been built into the minds of men. Frank McKee.
title: Says Men Must Adopt A New Set Of Ideas

entities.text: To the Editor of The Press:

author: J. W.
summary: The author expresses frustration with the state of the banking industry in the United States, lamenting the loss of confidence in banks due to poor practices and speculation. They call for stringent regulation of bank operations to restore public faith.
text:
HOW ABOUT ENGLAND

 To the Editor of The Press: I would like very much to know what has become of the great financiers we had in this country a few years ago, who rode on the crest of the wave of prosperity proclaiming to the world that we had the best and soundest monetary system in the universe. In England they have experienced a great depression for several years, have gone off the gold standard and yet more banks closed their doors in the state of Ohio in the past month than in England during 50 years. If the bankers in this country had devoted their energies to the ethics of sound banking instead of bucket-shop speculating we would not be in the most deplorable condition we find ourselves in today. There should be enacted at once some very stringent laws regulating the manner in which a bank may handle the funds of its depositors. Faith in banks as a safe depository has been terribly shattered and it will take years to restore the confidence of the public. Hillingdon.

be
title: How About England

entities.identity: Place name, likely a location in England given the reference to 'in England'

author: C. A. Quintrell
summary: The author, C. A. Quintrell, writes to express concern over the American Legion's ultimatum to an Army & Navy Post for not repudiating the endorsement of an economy bill introduced by President Roosevelt. They argue that such actions are contrary to democratic principles and free speech, which should be protected under the US Constitution. The author also recalls an article indicating opposition to veterans' legislation from several legion posts, including New England.
text:
FREE SPEECH IN THE LEGION

 To The Editor of The Press. The Army & Navy Post of the American Legion has been served with an ultimatum from the officials of the American Legion that it either repudiate the action of its executive committee in recommending the passage of the economy bill, sponsored by President Roosevelt, or suffer ejection from the legion. This information was contained in your paper of March 16th and in a statement sent by the adjutant of this post to all of its members. The American Legion is not and cannot function as a military machine. It may be that a member of a military organization in war times should obey without hesitancy or criticism any order given by a superior officer. No organization, however, operating in peace time in a democratic government whose constitution guarantees the right of free speech, can survive if it attempts to exercise such autocratic control of enforcement of gag rule. The economy bill was, as I understand it, introduced in the federal Congress at the request of the president of this country and certainly ho organization can be permitted by public opinion to eject members from its roster becanse of the fact that they or their representatives express an opinion upon such a bill, particularly one in favor of its adoption. The question as to whether or not the government should pay or should ever have made payments relating to disabilities having no connection with war-time service is one on which any citizen should be free to express his frank opinion. It is my recollection from an article by Alfred E. Smith in the Saturday Evening Post that not only isolated posts of the legion but in fact the New England department of the legion took an attitude of opposition toward a great deal of the veterans' legislation.

I am writing this to you as a member of Army & Navy Post and in the belief that it is high time that public opinion of this and other communities bring the officials charged with the conduct of the legion affairs to their 'sensés. and xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx military machine operating in war time with czaristic powers including that of gag rule. The legion as such is an extremely worthwhile American institutioil Dut it is very apparent its officials are departing wholly from the spirit of its constitution and from all standards of American conduct. C. A. Quintrell.
title: Free Speech In The Legion

author: Charles Wagner
summary: The letter's author, Charles Wagner, expresses frustration over the slow economic recovery since the 1929 stock market crash. He criticizes those who resisted economic measures to combat deflation, arguing that even a technical move towards inflation would be beneficial for the economy.
text:
NOW FOR INFLATION

 To the Editor of The Press: Ever since the stock market crash of 1929 wiped billions off we have been attempting to carry on business as usual with many millions less than the usual amount of the medium necessary to successfully transact business. When statesmen attempted to remedy this situation they were howled down as inflationists. "Never, never will we abanden-the gold standard," cried these howlers. People could starve and commerce slowly shrink to the limits of barter but the sacred golden calf must not be melted into usefulness. What a rude awakening awaited these ostriches in the proclamation which puts us off the gold standard, only technically, of course. Sugar coat the medicine by all means, tell them we refuse to honor our gold certificates but not really, only technically.

Now for inflation. Even technical inflation will be satisfactory. Charles Wagner.
title: Now For Inflation

author: Mrs. William Flaugher
summary: The letter complains about Mr. Raper's hypocrisy in not criticizing Robert Crosser for voting against President Roosevelt's economic relief bill, despite being his campaign manager. The writer also feels that the newspaper's editorial on Crosser was gentler than it would be towards a Republican for similar actions.
text:
CROSSER PROTECTED?

 To the Editor of The Prese: I got sore eyes trying to find a wise crack in Mr. Raper's column today referring to his candidate, Robert Crosser. If it had been anyone else who had voted against the half billion dollar measure of President Roosevelt's providing for economy, Mr. Raper would have wrathfully referred to him as a moròn or something along the same line. But because he was his campaign manager he neglects to treat Grosser as he would anyone else.

And by the way, Mr. Editor, your editorial commenting on Mr. Crosser's conduct was not the same kind of a fire-eating editorial you would write against a Republican, for example, if he had acted as Crosser did on the Roosevelt bill.

About the only person who has escaped the poison pen of Mr. Raper is Mr. Crosser, and I guess it is because he was his campaign manager.

"Consistency, thou art a jewel." Mrs. William Flaugher 3618 Tullamore road.
title: Crosser Protected?

entities.name: Robert Crosser
entities.identity: Candidate mentioned in the letter, possibly a political figure in the local area or state. His behavior and actions are scrutinized.

author: John McCarthy
summary: The letter expresses concern about the financial burden of farm relief on the government and argues that ultimately city dwellers will bear the cost, leading to decreased demand for farm goods and a worsening economy for everyone, especially farmers. The author suggests that fixing the farm problem should rely on market forces rather than governmental interference and blames political actions for economic conditions.
text:
WHO PAYS FOR FARM RELIEF?

 To the Editor of The Press:

Where will the government get the money to help the farmers? Answer: From the city man. Result: the city man will have less money. Further result: he will buy less farm goods. Final result: the whole nation will be worse off and especially the farmer, just as both are now worse off as a result of the activities of the Farm Board. There is only one way to cure the farm trouble, and that is to let farm products face the eternal law of supply and demand. Professor Moley knows that. Professor Tugwell knows it and Professor Taussig knows it. We will have to come to it in the end. In the meantime there is no sense in our repeating the colossal blunders of the past. It was not the Republicans who boosted the appropriations for the veterans during the boom years. It was the general prosperity of the country. Similarly it is not the Democrats who now are reducing those appropriations; it is the general poverty of the country. Politicians merely put into effect the measures made necessary by general social conditions.

John McCarthy 1730 W. 38th street.
title: Who Pays For Farm Relief?

author: Frank Mervar
summary: The author, Frank Mervar, endorses Adam J. Dammi for the position of safety directorship. He argues that Dammi's extensive record in public service and his level-headed leadership make him an ideal candidate. The letter calls on Mayor Ray T. Miller and the Democratic organization to be proud and appoint Dammi, citing his integrity and ability.
text:
SAYS DAMM IS THE MAN

 To The Editor of The Press.

Adam J. Damni is the logical man for the safety directorship. He would be welcomed by the public in general as well as the Police and Fire departments. That he is capable, his past record in public service of a great many years as councilman and city treasurer is outstanding: He is a level-headed and fearless leader. Mayor Ray T. Miller and the Democratic organization should be proud to have a man of Mr. Damm's integrity and ability in their cabinet. Frank Mervar 7801 Wade Park avenue.
title: Says Damm Is The Man

entities.text: To The Editor of The Press.
